DIESEL TAX ON TAXIS
(Request for review)


    1. Mr Goh Chee Wee asked the Minister for Finance and Minister for Health, in view of the substantial drop in demand for taxis after the introduction of the new fare structure and the consequent reduction of income of taxi drivers, if the Minister will consider reviewing or withholding the imposition of the taxi diesel tax.

     The Minister for Finance and Minister for Health (Dr Hu Tsu Tau): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, it is premature for me at this stage to consider reviewing or withholding the imposition of a diesel tax on taxis. My colleague, the Minister for Communications and Information has already informed Members of the measures he is taking with regard to taxi fares. In my view, the diesel tax should be imposed in order to reduce the gross disparity in operating costs between petrol-powered motor cars and diesel-powered taxis. However, if in September the Minister for Communications should advise me that it would be desirable to have some flexibility as regards the imposition of the diesel tax, I shall, of course, give his views very serious consideration.

     Mr Goh Chee Wee (Boon Lay): Sir, when the Minister said that he is prepared to review, does he mean that he is prepared to consider deferring the implementation of the tax, to introduce gradual changes or to even scrap the diesel tax altogether?

     Dr Hu Tsu Tau: As I said, it is premature to discuss any of these measures until the taxi fare situation is settled.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Supplementary question, Sir, for the Minister for Finance. Does he not think that the proper thing now would be to revoke the decision to implement the diesel tax as in the view

Column: 104

of the Ministry of Communications, there has been a totally unexpected drop in taxi drivers' earnings? And then consider whether a diesel tax should be introduced and, if so, by how much?

     Dr Hu Tsu Tau: The answer to the Member for Anson is no.

PHARMACEUTICAL FACTORY
(Investment in)


    2. Mr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for Finance and Minister for Health (a) what is the rationale of developing a pharmaceutical factory costing S$20 million and whether such a move contradicts the Government's policy of moving away from commercial activities; (b) whether the investment in the pharmaceutical factory is cost effective; (c) whether other multinational research-based pharmaceutical companies have committed themselves to invest in Singapore; and (d) whether the Government's plan to build the pharmaceutical factory will discourage other more substantial research-based pharmaceutical investments in Singapore.

    The Minister of State for Health and Foreign Affairs (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong) (for the Minister for Finance and Minister for Health): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I will answer on behalf of my Minister.

    The proposed pharmaceutical factory is intended to replace an old Government facility at Jalan Bukit Merah.

    Since 1950, the Ministry of Health has operated a pharmaceutical factory in an old converted warehouse at Jalan Bukit Merah. The factory is not engaged in the primary manufacture of active pharmaceutical ingredients but carries out the secondary pharmaceutical process of formulating, compounding and packaging of a wide range of generic or non-proprietary drugs into tablets, capsules, mixtures and injections, etc, for use within the Ministry's hospitals and outpatient dispensaries.

    This factory has provided our hospitals and dispensaries with a wide range of essential drugs at very economic prices. Without this facility, the Ministry would be obliged to purchase all its drug requirements in the form of proprietary drugs

Column: 105

from commercial sources at substantially higher prices. The Ministry's actual drug bill was $15.5 million in 1984 and would have been well over $20 million if patented proprietary drugs had been used.

    The demand for drugs and pharmaceutical products by Government hospitals and OPDs has increased at the rate of 5-7% a year for the past 10 years. This demand has outgrown the production capacity of the existing factory. This factory is severely short of space for production and storage, is poorly laid out and uses antiquated, labour-intensive techniques. The Ministry has plans to construct a new, modern, automated factory in its place.

    The proposed new factory will not in any way contradict Government's policy to move away from private sector commercial activities. It replaces an existing facility and its products will be used mainly in Government hospitals and clinics.

    (b) The new factory, which is estimated to cost approximately $26.5 million will employ the latest techniques of drug manufacturing including automated systems of production. It will be less labour-intensive. This will reduce the cost of the product as manpower costs account for a significant portion of production cost.

    The factory will concentrate mainly on the production of high consumption items to achieve economies of scale to be cost effective.

    It is estimated that the factory will result in a saving in the drug bill of approximately $4.5 million annually.

    (c) During the period 1980-84, the total investment in Singapore by the pharmaceutical industry amounted to approximately $194 million. The Economic Development Board does not foresee any major pharmaceutical investments in Singapore in the near future.

    (d) There are two stages in the production process for pharmaceuticals. The first is the primary manufacture of the active ingredients, and the second is the processing of the active ingredients into the finished form such as tablets, capsules,

Column: 106

mixtures, injections and ointments, etc. Primary manufacturing of active ingredients is both capital and technology intensive, and has a high value-added per worker. It requires a large investment capital to set up and for research and development. To be successful, a factory for the primary manufacture of active ingredients must have a market that is larger than what the Ministry of Health or Singapore can provide. On the other hand, secondary processing involves the formulation, compounding and packaging of generic productions into tablets, etc. It is less capital intensive and tends to be a local market orientated operation.

    The proposed manufacturing plant for the Ministry of Health is of the latter type and is meant to meet its own needs. It will therefore not in any way discourage research-oriented pharmaceutical companies from setting up manufacturing plants in Singapore.

Column: 106

WOODBRIDGE HOSPITAL
(Plans and programmes for discharged patients)


    3. Mr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for Finance and Minister for Health (a) what is the progress in the development of Woodbridge Hospital; (b) what are the plans to strengthen day and community care programmes for discharged patients who have been treated for psychiatric illness; and (c) what efforts are being made to promote a mental health education programme.

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong (for the Minister for Finance and Minister for Health): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the present Woodbridge Hospital was built in 1928. It was built at a time when the treatment of psychiatric patients was custodial with compulsory confinement in an institution isolated from the city centre. The many buildings which make up Woodbridge Hospital are spread over a very large area. They are old, out-moded, inefficient to manage and do not meet the needs of a modern psychiatric centre. As envisaged in the National Health Plan, the Ministry plans to demolish the present hospital and replace it with a new, compact and multistoreyed hospital complex that is in

Column: 107

keeping with a modern centre for psychiatric treatment.

    A Study Team comprising two Consultant Psychiatrists and two Architects recently visited new psychiatric hospitals in Hong Kong, Canada and the United States. A Planning Committee is being established to prepare a Master Plan for the redevelopment of Woodbridge Hospital. The team will be finalizing the plans to submit to the Ministry and the Ministry hopes to obtain approval for the building of the new Psychiatric Centre and to commence construction work in 1986. The project should be completed within three years.

    The main thrust in modern psychiatric treatment is on non-institutional ambulatory or outpatient care. The Ministry's future plans for day and community care programmes for discharged patients will include the following:

    (i) Increasing the number of Psychiatric Outpatient Clinics for the follow-up treatment of patients discharged from hospital and for those who do not require hospitalization because of the early or mild nature of their illness. At present, there are a number of Specialist Outpatient Clinics at Woodbridge Hospital. There are also five Psychiatric Outpatient Clinics at Maxwell, Bedok, Pegu, Bukit Merah and Lim Ah Pin Polyclinics/Outpatient Dispensaries. Additional Psychiatric Outpatient Clinics at Polyclinics to be developed at Woodlands South, Yishun and Bukit Batok are being planned for the next three to four years.

    (ii) There are two Day Centres, namely, the Mandalay and Alexandra Day Centres. These centres have proved effective in rehabilitating discharged psychiatric patients and preparing them for return to the community. At these centres, patients undergo group therapy and are given training for simple job assignments in a sheltered environment. They are paid a token allowance based on their output. The maximum capacity of both Centres is 180 patients at any one time. In 1984, both Centres took in a total of 525 new cases and found employment in private firms for 99 patients. The Ministry is considering setting up a third Day Centre at the Lim Ah Pin Polyclinic.

Column: 108



    (iii) The Ministry is considering developing psychiatric units in general hospitals for the less severe mentally disturbed cases. A ward in Tan Tock Seng Hospital will be converted to function as a psychiatric unit by the end of this year. Similar units will be established in Toa Payoh and Alexandra Hospitals to provide inpatient, outpatient and day treatment. This way we hope to treat the early or mild cases of psychiatric disorder within a general hospital rather than purely in Woodbridge Hospital.

    The promotion of mental health will be a part of the Ministry's overall health education programme. This programme seeks to promote both the physical and mental health of school children, patients, the workforce and the community through healthy lifestyle. One of the priority activities in this programme is educating the public on stress management. This will be done through seminars, health fairs, talks and information materials. For example, a seminar on stress control was conducted for secondary school teachers last month. A stress management booth was included in the Health Fair held on World Health Day on 6th April this year.

    In addition, Woodbridge Hospital will continue with its various educational activities such as the following:

    (i) Educating patients and their relatives on the symptoms and treatment of mental illness, the need to seek medical advice and treatment early and regular follow up to ensure maximum success in treatment. Relatives will be taught to cope with patients after their discharge.

    (ii) Staff will give talks on mental health to interested groups, for example, at schools and work places. Interviews, talks and articles will be given through the mass media. A series of articles on mental health contributed by the Hospital's Psychiatrists will be featured in the news media in the near future.

    (iii) Hospital staff will continue to work closely with the Singapore Mental Health Association in its mental health education programme and will promote activities that will benefit psychiatric patients.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, may I know from the Minister of State the range of fees that are being charged at Woodbridge Hospital? I suppose there must be patients in this Hospital who have been there for a considerable length of time. Are they being charged at the rate that is being prescribed for short-term patients? Does the Ministry consider the hardship of families who may not be able to meet these fees?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: For long-term stay in the Hospital, no fees are charged if they are unable to pay. In fact, we have many patients who have been staying in the hospital for many years and who have not been paying a single cent. Most of them do not have to pay, mainly because they have been left there by their families who are unable to take them home. Therefore, we have not been charging most of such patients.

    The fees for the outpatient clinics are also very minimal and if the Member wants to know, I can provide him with the whole range of the fees.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: May I know further from the Minister of State the class of patients who have been exempted from payment of fees? Do they come from the public assistance cases only or do they range beyond that?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: They are not just restricted to those on the public assistance programme.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: If I may move away from the fees to the question of patients who may not be too ill to be in the hospital but it may not be safe to keep at home. I understood from the Minister of State that the tendency is to try and keep them out of hospital. Two years ago, there was a suggestion that half-way homes might be set up. May I know whether any progress has been made in this direction?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: The present trend, on a world-wide basis, is to try and retain those who are less mentally ill in the home environment so that they are not fully isolated from a real-life situation. For those who are violent, for those who are unable to be restrained at home, they can be referred to the Woodbridge Hospital and

Column: 110

most of those cases are retained at Woodbridge Hospital for observation, which normally stretches from between four and six weeks. If they are found to be suitable for release, they will then be released to their own homes where the home environment is more conducive to their recovery. However, they will be given the proper medication to ensure that they are under the correct treatment.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, can the Minister of State please tell us the number of persons who are suffering from psychiatric illness and who are at the moment receiving attention at all the outpatient clinics?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: I am sorry I do not have the figures at hand. But if the hon. Member likes, I will arrange to send it to him.

     Mr S. Vasoo (Bo Wen): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, in view of the high population centres and families are now relocated in various housing estates, would the Ministry be reviewing its outpatient services with a view to providing better support for discharged patients because it is a problem for patients to get access to the existing outpatient services?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: As I have stated earlier, we have current plans to expand the various outpatient clinics and specialist outpatient clinics. However, there is a limit as to how fast we can expand because of the availability of trained personnel. The hon. Member can be assured that we have a programme and we will be taking steps to implement the programme as stated.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Sir, I am sorry, but would the Minister of State be good enough to answer whether there is any plan to proceed with the setting up of halfway homes for people who are not too ill to be in hospital but who perhaps are not safe to be kept at home, especially where children are present?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: There are no plans at the moment. But it is still under study in terms of the overall health care services.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: It was under study two years ago.

Column: 111



     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam (Fengshan): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, there is a Unit in Woodbridge Hospital looking after the chronic sick. In the redevelopment plans of Woodbridge Hospital, will this Unit be retained or expanded?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: I understand the Unit looking after the chronic sick and the aged has been taken over by the Ministry of Community Development.

     Mr S. Vasoo: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, what are the plans that are being currently undertaken to rehabilitate and reintegrate the chronic patients of Woodbridge Hospital into community life?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: The plan has always been to try to rehabilitate them and, for those who have been cured, to release them back to their families.

PARLIAMENTARY OPPOSITION
(Motion)


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [14th May, 1985],

    "That this House regrets the obstructionist attitude of this Government to the growth of a genuine Parliamentary Opposition in Singapore in accordance with the will of the electorate.". - [Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam].

    Question again proposed.
11.22 am

     Dr Lau Teik Soon (Serangoon Gardens): Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for giving me this opportunity to participate in this debate.

    Sir, the Member for Anson, since his entry into this Chamber, has frequently talked about the lack of parliamentary democracy, the suppression of individual freedom, fundamental rights, freedom of organization, freedom of free expression and so on. I think most Singaporeans will not agree with his view that in Singapore there exists a form of totalitarian state where there is suppression of individual freedom, where there is no opportunity for people to express themselves.

    Over the years, since 1959 when the People's Action Party came to power, there have been considerable opportunities for the people at large to develop their

Column: 112

participation in the political process. There have been elections since 1959, not just general elections but also by-elections. Anyone who has the qualifications can participate. Anyone can put out statements to the press. So there is no obstruction on the part of the Government to prevent the development of the political process in this country.

    Of course, the Opposition Member may be referring to the constraints which are imposed on the practice of what may be called liberal democracy in this country. I would accept that. There have to be certain constraints in the practice of parliamentary democracy.

    Before coming to that, Sir, may I just mention this very briefly. When one talks about parliamentary democracy, which model of parliamentary democracy are we talking about? I think that the Opposition Members have constantly in their minds the model of the United States or the United Kingdom or the Western democracies where you have considerable liberal democratic practices with very limited constraints. I do not say that there is complete freedom of the individual to do whatever he likes, to express his views and so on. There are constraints within those democracies as well.

    But the consequences of liberal democracies like those in the United States and the UK are evident for all to see. There are the positive aspects of their parliamentary system, but there are also the consequences which are evident. One can see the social dissent within those countries, the rampant strikes, the unemployment, the relatively low standard of living on the part of certain sectors in society. There are slums within those countries. Today, one can see, for example, the large unemployment in the United Kingdom and in the Western European countries. On social matters, in those countries, there is such liberalization that the people are beginning to react against those freedoms. For example, the question of freedom of the press or the dissemination of pornographic materials. The people are beginning to react against such rampant individualism which exists in those countries. That is not the type of democracy that we would want in Singapore.

Column: 113



    On the other hand, there are also those countries which call themselves democracies but are in fact authoritarian states, one-party states. Many of us, Sir, including you, have been involved in meetings of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association, the Inter-Parliamentary Union, and all those countries say they are parliamentary democracies. Look at those countries where they have one-party system. Are they democracies? But they call themselves parliamentary democracies. Again, that is not the sort of model that we want to look at.

    So, Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, when we talk about parliamentary democracy in any country and, particularly, in our case, we have to look at the system which is most suitable to our social, our economic and our political conditions. There are certain factors inherent in our society which, if allowed free expression, could lead to political instability. Let me just mention some of these constraints.

    We are a multi-racial society. If we allow for freedom of expression without constraints as far as racial issues are concerned, then there could be considerable racial conflicts existing in the society. We have experiences of racial riots. Therefore, there has to be this constraint. No political Party, no politician can be allowed to champion racial or ethnic causes to the detriment of others existing in our society.

    Then there is the question of ideology. Those in the West would say we are not a democratic country because we do not allow the Marxist-Leninist Party to exist. So we are not a democracy. Clearly, if we allow such an ideology to exist in this country, then you create deep divisions because the brand of Marxism-Leninism in this part of the world is very akin to a major Asian power and that has racial overtones. So we cannot allow for that. Does it mean that we are not, therefore, a parliamentary democracy?

    Then there is the question of the trade unions and whether they have the automatic right to strike. These issues have been taken up in the Western press, and the Opposition Members, I am sure, are

Column: 114

keen readers of the Western press. They are aware of the issues which are brought forward by the Western journalists. Industrial stability is crucial to our political development, to our nation-building, to our economic growth. We cannot allow for any employee who feels like it to down his tools and then to have the executives in the union to go on strike automatically, as can happen in the Western democracies. Here, we have a very regulated, due process of settling industrial disputes. So we have the Industrial Relations Act and the Employment Act. Does it mean then that we are not a democracy? This has to be so, the need to have industrial stability, because it is vital, imperative for political stability, for economic growth. And this leads to the other factor that we must always bear in mind, that Singapore has very limited resources, ie, land and manpower. And we have to be overly dependent on foreign countries for trade, for investments, and so on.

    We have to be concerned with the political systems in our neighbouring countries. So when we talk about parliamentary democracy and its practice, we must be aware that there have to be constraints because of the limitations of the kind of society we are.

    Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the Member for Anson in his motion talked about the growth of parliamentary Opposition. Any political Party that aspires to grow must have, among other things, effective leadership. Does his Party have effective leadership? The Party must have a good organization. Has his Party a good organization? The Party must be able to appeal to voters. Has his Party the appeal? And last but not least, it must have a good programme. Here, in this Chamber, Sir, Ministers of the Government have constantly asked the Opposition Member: What is your programme? What are your proposals? What suggestions can you give to enhance our economic growth, full employment, eradication of poverty? There was no response whatsoever. No programme. No effective organization. No effective leadership.

    So, Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, may I suggest to the Member for Anson that if he aspires to develop the Opposition, he must fulfil these pre-requisites. And one of the

Column: 115

first things that he has to do would be, of course, to have a thorough house cleaning of his Party and to inject new blood so that it may have some prospect of continued existence.
11.35 am

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Industry (Encik Sidek bin Saniff)( In Malay): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir,I am Sidek Saniff from Kolam Ayer.

    I wish to thank the Member for Anson for retracing history back to 1956 and quoting the speech made by our Prime Minister when he was in the Opposition in the then Legislative Assembly. I only wish that the Member had made a deep reflection as to why after only three years in the Opposition, he could become the Prime Minister, and since 1959 had continuously been the Prime Minister and carried on with the task of delivering the goods to the people of Singapore, although his comrades have been succeeded by new activists to shoulder the responsibilities of governing Singapore in the years ahead.

    To my mind, there is only one very important factor that has brought about the Prime Minister's success and the success of his colleagues and the Government. And that is, there is no other way for Singapore to survive other than to be governed on the basis of one fundamental factor, without compromising anything: that the government of the day must take cognizance of Singapore's plural mix, its multi-racial, multi-lingual and multireligious society. We are also aware that there are several countries whose security is ensured only if their politicians, their armies and religious groups are united. There are also countries which need the services of the immigrant population, irrespective of whether they have become citizens or not, to help run these countries. However, for us, the foundation of our survival rests only on multi-lingualism, multi-culturalism and multi-religions. That is why if you take even an overview, you will find that the three major communities in Singapore, on every election, without fail, have been fielded by this Government. And, Praise be to God, until today we have

Column: 116

been elected by the people, except for one or two seats over the last two to three years which the Opposition Members have been able to penetrate. So, basically, it is the credibility of the person that counts. Hence, over a period of three years, he succeeded in becoming the Prime Minister and continues to govern Singapore till now.

    Sir, I do not wish to be rude to the Member. He has also been occupying his seat for more or less three years now, but he is alone (from his Party) in this Chamber. I am sorry, I do not want to be arrogant, but it is a fact that he is so engrossed with this desire that I could feel it when he levelled his criticisms right from the debate on the President's Address until the Budget Debate. Since this aspect has already been dealt with by my colleague, the Member for Serangoon Gardens, Dr Lau Teik Soon, I see no need for me to cover the same ground.

    And what amazes me is that this is the person who has been elected by the Anson community, hoping that he could bring about some changes, some credibility, of course some form of respect could be accorded him. Or is it because some aspects of our policy, the public tone of the Government and its operational style has changed that has enabled him to enter Parliament, or perhaps by default, and only God knows best (wallahua'lam)? Nevertheless, I accept the two factors as facts. However, it was rather disgusting to me to note that on one occasion when the Speaker asked whether he was asking a question or making innuendoes after aving made the innuendoes, his reply was that he was only asking questions.

    So, we felt as though we on this side of the Bench are being enslaved. Or perhaps by his answer, he desires to enslave the Singapore society. Because we are all aware that in a defendant's defence, a lawyer has recourse to three ways. It may be inconsistent with each other but they will all be found to belong to one or other of three types. For example, he can resort to traverse, confession and avoidance, the third an objection in point of law. I think when we become the elected representatives of the people in this Chamber, we must maintain our credibility and conduct

Column: 117
